definition: to say a matter has no relationship with the individual referred to, to emphasise one is innocent or in the clear
to cast away/to fling aside
to throw/to cast/left-slanting downward brush stroke (calligraphy)
Qing or Ch'ing dynasty of imperial China (1644-1911)/surname Qing
clear/distinct/quiet/just and honest/pure/to settle or clear up/to clean up or purge

sentences.english: He proposed that the Council should disassociate itself from such behaviour.
sentences.chinese: 他提議委員會應同這種行爲撇清關係。

sentences.english: I wish to disassociate myself from this very sad decision.
sentences.chinese: 我希望我同這個令人遺憾的決定撇清關係。

sentences.english: Besides, this is my family matter. You should stay out of it.
sentences.chinese: 另外，這是我的家事，你最好與此撇清關係。

sentences.english: I am just clearing that up. In fact, I am pretty sure I have at least one friend from each of the races (Hi, Guillermo).
sentences.chinese: 我只是想撇清，事實上我在每個種族裏幾乎都有朋友。

definition: clear (of liquid)/limpid/to clarify/to make sth clear/to be clear (about the facts)
to settle (of liquid)/to become clear (by precipitation of impurities)/precipitate (chemistry)/to put in order/to quell disturbances
to exculpate/to absolve/to exonerate
to have an acrimonious falling-out/to shed all pretense of cordiality/to tear into each other
to offer an explanation/to plead innocence/to try to defend oneself
lit. to pull sb into the water/to involve sb in a messy business/to get sb into trouble
clear dividing line/to distinguish clearly
see 撕破臉|撕破脸[si1 po4 lian3]
(lit.) to splash dirty water/(fig.) to throw mud at/to smear (sb)
to illuminate/to open up (a topic)
not to get involved/to stay out of it
to avoid arousing suspicion
lit. the more you touch things up, the darker they get/fig. to only make matters worse
variant of 趟渾水|趟浑水[tang1 hun2 shui3]
to deny flatly
to fall out with sb/to become hostile
to frame sb (by planting sth on them)
